Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Neurobiological Regulation and Psychosocial Responses to Terrorism and Hate Crimes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Terrorist attacks and hate crimes have pervasive impacts that extend beyond the direct victims of these crimes. Due to the vast reach of social media, the sympathy, distress, fear and outrage that such crimes provoke can extend across the country. Research has found that the stress of experiencing traumatic events like terrorist attacks and natural disasters can have strong neurobiological and psychological effects on direct victims and related family members. However, there has been very little research on whether there are similar immediate and lasting effects on those people who are physically distant and unrelated, yet feel connected to, the victims. When a traumatic event is both a terrorist attack and a violent hate crime targeting members of an identifiable group, others who feel a shared identity with that group may be affected by such an event in even more profound ways. The investigator Paul Hastings (University of California, Davis) tests these hypotheses in the aftermath of a recent mass shooting event in Florida. The investigator draws from social psychology theories of identity and minority stress, and biological psychology theories of allostatic load and stress physiology to test whether the degree of shared identity with the victims of the massacre moderates the impacts on individuals geographically distant from the event. The neurobiological and psychological impacts immediately after the event are assessed as well as recovery from these effects over the following six months. By extending science's understanding of how shared identity status shapes the broader community's neurobiological processes and psychosocial adjustment following targeted terrorist attacks and hate crimes, this RAPID project will identify factors that may promote recovery from such traumatic events. This will inform efforts to design community-focused program to build resilience in relevant groups, and interventions to reduce the negative effects of catastrophic social injustices.

The investigator uses the naturally occurring event of a recent mass shooting to test key hypotheses about the impact of shared identity status -- specifically, ethnic and sexual identity -- on response to geographically distant events. The terrorist attack and hate crime that occurred on Latin night at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Florida in June 2016 is the largest mass-shooting massacre in modern U.S. history. The targets and direct victims of this massacre were predominantly young adult members of a multiple-minority group: the LGBTQ Latino/a community. Thus, the current research involves a sample of LGBTQ Latino/a, plus comparison samples of straight Latino/a, LGBTQ White, and straight White young adults from the metropolitan area of a city in northern California that is of similar size to Orlando. These groups systematically vary in either sharing or not sharing both the sexual identity and ethnic/racial identity characteristics of the majority of the victims of the Orlando massacre. Within two months of the massacre, participants complete questionnaires to assess identity relevant variables, experiences of stressful life events and of victimization, and measures of psychological well-being and mental health. Over two consecutive days, participants then provide multiple saliva samples, and complete additional questionnaire measures. The saliva samples will be used to assess levels of a stress hormone, cortisol, and two inflammatory cytokines, interleukin-6 and c-reactive protein, to measure activity of the immunological system. These measures are repeated six months later.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hate crimes have pervasive impacts that extend beyond the direct victims of these crimes. Research has found that the stress of experiencing traumatic events like terrorist attacks or hate crimes can have strong neurobiological and psychological effects on direct victims and related family members. Although limited, some research suggests there are similar immediate and lasting effects on people who are physically distant and unrelated, yet feel connected to, the victims through ripple effects. When a traumatic event is a violent hate crime targeting members of an identifiable group, others who feel a shared identity with that group may be affected by such an event in even more profound ways. The investigator Paul Hastings (University of California, Davis) and co-investigator Luis Parra tested these hypotheses in the aftermath of a recent mass shooting event in Florida. The investigators drew from social psychology theories of identity and oppression, and biological psychology theories of allostatic load and stress physiology to test whether the degree of shared identity with the victims of the massacre moderates the impacts on individuals geographically distant from the event. The neurobiological and psychological impacts immediately after the event were assessed as well as recovery from these effects over the following months. By extending science's understanding of how shared identity status shapes the broader community's neurobiological processes and psychosocial adjustment following targeted hate crimes, this RAPID project tried to identify factors that may promote recovery from such traumatic events. This will inform efforts to design community-focused program to build resilience in relevant groups, and interventions to reduce the negative effects of catastrophic social injustices.

The investigators assessed whether there was heightened stress neurobiology activity in people with shared identity status -- specifically, ethnic and sexual identity -- in response to a geographically distant mass shooting, relative to individuals without those identity characteristics. When it occurred, the hate crime on Latin night at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Florida in June 2016 was the largest mass-shooting massacre in modern U.S. history. The targets and direct victims of this massacre were predominantly young adult members of a multiple-minority group: the LGBTQ Latinx community. This study included people who identified as LGBTQ Latinx, plus comparison samples of Straight Latinx, LGBTQ White, and Straight White young adults from multiple metropolitan areas in northern California. Within two months of the massacre, participants (N = 202) completed questionnaires that assessed their identity and demographics, experiences of stressful life events and of heterosexist and racist discrimination, and measures of psychological well-being and mental health. Over two consecutive days, participants then provided multiple saliva samples, and completed additional questionnaire measures. The saliva samples were used to assess levels of a stress hormone, cortisol, and one inflammatory cytokine, interleukin-6 (IL-6), to measure activity of the immunological system. These measures were repeated nine months later. Counter to expectations, the LGBTQ Latinx, Straight Latinx, LGBTQ White, and Straight White young adults did not differ in the levels of salivary cortisol and IL-6 produced by their bodies, either immediately after or nine months after the Pulse Night Club massacre. Although this implies that shared identity status did not influence the degree to which the massacre had distal effects on individual stress neurobiology, the investigators are continuing to examine the data to determine whether there were individuals within each of the four identity groups who may have been more or less susceptible to influence. In addition, their work is beginning to show that personal experiences of having been the target of heterosexist and racist discrimination are predictive of identity integration and cortisol production within the LGBTQ Latinx people. Specifically, LGBTQ Latinx participants who experienced more heterosexist and racist discrimination reported increased difficulty with forming an integrated identity that incorporated both their ethnic and their sexual identities, and in turn, this identity conflict predicted lower waking salivary cortisol, which is a marker of fatigue or diminished capacity within the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis system.
